metadata.title: Labels | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing Labels - static pieces of text that people can read and copy but not edit. The document covers best practices for label usage, platform-specific considerations, system label colors, and related developer resources across Apple platforms.
metadata.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: Labels
A label is a static piece of text that people can read and often copy, but not edit.

content.description: A stylized illustration showing a label component in Apple's design language. The image features a coral/salmon pink rounded rectangle card on a light pink/peach gradient background. The card contains the word 'Label' in large black text. Below the label text is a specification line reading 'System Font - Body (Emphasized)' and 'Primary Text Color' indicating the typography and color specifications. A small red circular element appears in the top right corner of the card, and abstract geometric shapes in various soft pink and peach tones create a modern, layered background effect.
content.composition: Centered card element on gradient background with decorative geometric shapes
content.technicalDetails: Demonstrates the visual appearance of a standard label component with System Font Body Emphasized styling and Primary Text Color
content.contextualRelevance: Hero image illustrating what a label component looks like in Apple's design system, showing the standard typography and color specifications

content.text: Labels display text throughout the interface, in buttons, menu items, and views, helping people understand the current context and what they can do next.
The term label refers to uneditable text that can appear in various places. For example:

items.text: Within a button, a label generally conveys what the button does, such as Edit, Cancel, or Send.
Within many lists, a label can describe each item, often accompanied by a symbol or an image.
Within a view, a label might provide additional context by introducing a control or describing a common action or task that people can perform in the view.

content.title: Developer note
content.text: To display uneditable text, SwiftUI defines two components: Label and Text.

The guidance below can help you use a label to display text. In some cases, guidance for specific components — such as action buttons, menus, and lists and tables — includes additional recommendations for using text.
Best practices

Use a label to display a small amount of text that people don't need to edit. If you need to let people edit a small amount of text, use a text field. If you need to display a large amount of text, and optionally let people edit it, use a text view.
content.leadingText: Use a label to display a small amount of text that people don't need to edit.

content.text: Prefer system fonts. A label can display plain or styled text, and it supports Dynamic Type (where available) by default. If you adjust the style of a label or use custom fonts, make sure the text remains legible.

Use system-provided label colors to communicate relative importance. The system defines four label colors that vary in appearance to help you give text different levels of visual importance. For additional guidance, see Color.
content.leadingText: Use system-provided label colors to communicate relative importance.

cells.content: Text that describes an unavailable item or behavior

content.tableSummary: A reference table showing the four system-provided label colors (Label, Secondary label, Tertiary label, Quaternary label) with their example usage contexts and the corresponding API property names for iOS/iPadOS/tvOS/visionOS and macOS platforms. The colors provide visual hierarchy from primary information down to watermark-level text.

content.text: Make useful label text selectable. If a label contains useful information — like an error message, a location, or an IP address — consider letting people select and copy it for pasting elsewhere.
Platform considerations
No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, or visionOS.
macOS

content.title: Developer note
content.text: To display uneditable text in a label, use the isEditable property of NSTextField.
watchOS

Date and time text components (shown below on the left) display the current date, the current time, or a combination of both. You can configure a date text component to use a variety of formats, calendars, and time zones. A countdown timer text component (shown below on the right) displays a precise countdown or count-up timer. You can configure a timer text component to display its count value in a variety of formats.

content.description: Two Apple Watch faces displayed side by side demonstrating date/time labels and timer labels. The left watch shows a date and time text component displaying formatted date and time information. The right watch shows a countdown timer text component displaying a countdown or count-up value.
content.composition: Two watch faces side by side, left showing date/time, right showing timer
content.technicalDetails: watchOS interface showing system-provided date and timer text components
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the specialized date/time and timer label components available on watchOS

content.text: Date and time labels
Timer label

When you use the system-provided date and timer text components, watchOS automatically adjusts the label's presentation to fit the available space. The system also updates the content without further input from your app.
Consider using date and timer components in complications. For design guidance, see Complications; for developer guidance, see Text.
content.leadingText: Consider using date and timer components in complications.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Developer Documentation page for Labels - a component for displaying static, non-editable text. The page covers the definition and use cases for labels (in buttons, lists, views), best practices including using system fonts, system label colors for visual hierarchy, and making useful text selectable. Platform-specific guidance is provided for macOS (using NSTextField with isEditable) and watchOS (date/time and timer text components). Resources section links to related HIG pages (Text fields, Text views) and developer documentation for Label, Text (SwiftUI), UILabel (UIKit), and NSTextField (AppKit).

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Design navigation bar with Overview, What's New, Get Started, Guidelines, Resources
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple Developer footer with platform links, tools, topics, resources, support, account, and programs

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Defines what a label is - a static piece of text that people can read and copy but not edit. Provides examples of label usage in buttons, lists, and views.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Four key guidelines: 1) Use labels for small non-editable text, 2) Prefer system fonts with Dynamic Type support, 3) Use system label colors (primary, secondary, tertiary, quaternary) for visual hierarchy, 4) Make useful label text selectable for copying.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: macOS
subsections.summary: For macOS, use NSTextField with isEditable property set to false to display uneditable label text.

subsections.title: watchOS
subsections.summary: watchOS provides specialized date/time text components and countdown timer text components. System automatically adjusts presentation to fit available space and updates content automatically. Recommends using these in complications.

sections.summary: Platform-specific guidance. No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, or visionOS. macOS uses NSTextField. watchOS has specialized date/time and timer label components.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to Text fields and Text views HIG pages.

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to Label (SwiftUI), Text (SwiftUI), UILabel (UIKit), and NSTextField (AppKit) documentation.

sections.summary: Related HIG resources and developer API documentation references for implementing labels across Apple frameworks.

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Document revision history showing one update on June 5, 2023 to reflect watchOS 10 changes.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with a definition of labels and their use cases, followed by best practices for implementation. Platform-specific considerations address macOS and watchOS unique requirements. The resources section provides links for further reading and API documentation. A change log tracks document revisions.

keyTerms.definition: A static piece of text that people can read and often copy, but not edit
Apple's system for supporting user-preferred text sizes, supported by labels by default
Four predefined colors (label, secondaryLabel, tertiaryLabel, quaternaryLabel) that provide visual hierarchy
Component for editable small amounts of text
Component for displaying and optionally editing large amounts of text
AppKit class used for labels on macOS, with isEditable property set to false
watchOS feature where date and timer text components can be used

keyFindings: Labels are for displaying small amounts of non-editable text throughout the interface
System fonts with Dynamic Type support should be preferred for labels
Four system label colors provide visual hierarchy: primary (Label), secondary, tertiary, and quaternary
Label text containing useful information (error messages, locations, IP addresses) should be selectable
macOS requires using NSTextField with isEditable set to false for labels
watchOS provides specialized date/time and countdown timer text components that auto-adjust to available space
SwiftUI provides both Label and Text components for displaying uneditable text

designDecisions.decision: Use labels for non-editable text display
designDecisions.rationale: Labels provide a consistent, accessible way to display static information
System fonts support Dynamic Type by default, ensuring accessibility
Four levels of visual prominence help users understand relative importance of information
Users may need to copy error messages, locations, or IP addresses for use elsewhere
